text: Jane had a stuffed toy chimpanzee named
Jubilee Jane Jane where are you she
cherished Jubilee and took him
everywhere she went everyone had been
searching for hours and hours looking
for little Valerie Jane Goodall Jane
Goodall to me it's almost like a
religious figure the piece that she
seems to carry with her calmness she has
the mind of a scientist but the heart of
a poet looking directly into my eyes he
very gently squeezed my fingers which is
how chimpanzees reassure each other this
is New York Times children's book editor
Pamela Paul it's a fortuitous
coincidence for young children that this
spring there are two new picture books
about Jane Goodall the world's leading
authority on chimpanzees and a tireless
advocate for protecting their
disappearing habitat I spoke with the
authors of both books and with good ol
who collaborated with author and
illustrator patrick mcdonald on me Jean
well the message I always try to get
across which is what Patrick picked up
on in the book is that you know if you
have a dream as a child you should
follow that dream even if people laugh
at you as they laughed at me for my
dream her life really shows how you know
one person can change the world and it
started at such an early age which was
really like predestined me Jane begins
with a young good ole receiving a
stuffed chimp named Jubilee as a gift
the story highlights the qualities she
possessed as a little girl that would
come to define her career as a scientist
patients inquisitiveness and a love of
the outdoors from a very young age I
just knew I wanted to do something with
animals I didn't know what but I was
watching them and writing about them and
making up stories about them me Jane
even contains detailed drawings and
diagrams that good all herself made as a
child
in contrast to me Jane the watcher jane
goodall's life with the chimps follows
her life trajectory from her native
England gumby park in Tanzania Africa
where she patiently gained the trust of
the chimpanzees there and discovered
that they used tools and kissed and
behaved more like humans than anyone had
realized just design-wise the pictures
at home are very small and confined and
when she finally reaches gombe i use
full you know double-page spreads and so
it just expands out I was you know
trying to show you know that she was
finally where she wanted to be and she
could let her passion flower I was just
so taken by the little dynamo Jane is a
young girl you know that's been
particularly the story of her going into
the chicken coop both authors included
the story of a four-year-old good ol
hiding out in a chicken coop for hours
she wanted to figure out how something
is big and hard as an egg could come out
of her head if you look back on that
whole story isn't it the making of a
little scientist curiosity asking
questions not getting the right answer
trying to find out for yourself not the
internet didn't exist back then so doing
it wrong not giving up and learning
patience the whole thing and the books
that you read were also influential dr.
Dolittle was the first actually because
you know he was this wonderful doctor
who learned the language of animals and
gosh I wanted to do that and then I find
the books about Tarzan I think that was
somewhere between 10 and 11 and of
course it was the books you know today
kids you know they get it on TV you were
outdoors all the time with a lot of free
time exploring observing do you see a
big difference now in the way that
children lead their lives yes a huge
difference in in in the US and the UK
especially but you know all the time is
organized so they do after school they
do swimming they do dancing they do this
kind of sport they do that and parents
driving them here there and everywhere
we just off to school we were on our own
we had our friends we went out on the
cliffs with my dog and we were free and
how important was that kind of time
spent outdoors in the open and a time to
becoming a scientist I think it was very
very important because always I was
watching and making notes and seeing the
spiders carrying eggs and then babies on
their backs and watching caterpillars
turn into butterflies and you know
watching a little plant grow all those
things were really important for me one
of the other big concerns today in
addition to children not having the free
time to be outdoors and exploring is
that girls are not interested in science
and that when you look at the number of
women who pursue advanced degrees in
science it's still not as high as in
other areas why do you think that is I
think it's because science has come to
be thought of as a rather cold you know
like when I first went to Cambridge
University I hadn't been to college when
I began the chimps and I was told well
you shouldn't have given the chimps
names they should have had numbers its
most scientific and you can't talk about
them having personalities your minds or
feelings because those are unique to us
so you know there's a perception that to
be a good scientist you must be cold and
objective so what else do you think that
parents and educators and book authors
and all of us could do to help encourage
girls to pursue the sciences you know to
be a good scientist you should be a
human being first and a scientist second
not the other way around and you know so
that so that there are certain qualities
which I think are particularly
pronounced in in women girls and that is
empathy and intuition and that this
shouldn't be squashed out that it's part
of who you are who we are it's something
that's very it should be very special
and unique and so the lesson is use your
intuition and from that you may get a
feeling of
standing you wouldn't have otherwise
from that point you can then test
whether you're feeling is right
